summary: Respected medical lecturer Dr. Frederick Frankenstein (Gene Wilder) learns that he has inherited his infamous grandfather's estate in Transylvania. Arriving at the castle, Dr. Frankenstein soon begins to recreate his grandfather's experiments with the help of servants Igor (Marty Feldman), Inga (Teri Garr) and the fearsome Frau Blücher (Cloris Leachman). After he creates his own monster (Peter Boyle), new complications ensue with the arrival of the doctor's fiancée, Elizabeth (Madeline Kahn).

reviews.content: Perfect writing and a perfect cast this is Mel brooks's masterpiece and probably the best comedy movie ever made

LOL, the funniest 1.75 hours ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Starring Gene Wilder, Peter Boyle, and Marty Feldman, directed by Mel Brooks!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! DVD and Blu-Ray Disc versions contain blooper reel, interviews in English and Spanish, interviews with Gene Wilder and Mel Brooks, etc.!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Hilarious. Gene Wilder's performance is outstanding
Brilliant sendup, with dozens of great lines and a funny, funny cast. ( "Ain't got no body…")
Classic: The only movie I ever gave 5 stars, and the only movie I enjoy watching over...and over.
They are the actual Royals

This is my all time favourite movie.  I am a huge Star Wars fan, but this still beats Empire into second place.

It brilliantly tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, the Grandson of the original Dr Frankenstein, who inherits the Family Castle.  Gene Wilder is excellent as Dr Fronkensteen.  Marty Feldman is great as Igor, not Egor, with his spot on comedic timing, Teri Garr is unbelievable sexy as Inga.  Mel Brooks' regulars Cloris Leachman as Frau Blücher (Horses whinny) and Madeline Khan as Elizabeth are as funny as ever.  And of course cannot forget Peter Boyle as The Monster...

Filmed in Black & White, to pay homage to the original 1933 movie, it also borrowed the original movie's equipment.  The fact it's in Black & White stupidly puts a lot of people off one of the greatest comedies, of all time.

Gene Wilder's only stipulation was that Mel Brooks was not allowed to be in front of the camera and it shows.  All his talent and skill are ensuring that each scene is hilarious, with loads of visual gags.  I personally feel that it is his masterpiece.

Look out for the cameo, off Gene Hackman, as the blind man...
This is probably my favorite comedy of all time. Classic Mel Brooks. Excellent casting with great acting and a typical goofy take on Frankenstein.  Absolute loved it.
Brilliant and hilarious!
It was good but old 👍🏼
A magnificent homage to the original horror classic while also being brilliantly funny and witty.

This is how you incorporate well thought humor to one of the most tragic stories of all time. Must watch! It is better to watch it after reading the book though to compare this modified story with the original one.
A fun spoof on an original classic

Young Frankenstein is a classic Mel Brooks comedy. That does not mean that every joke still lands decades after it was released, but many do. And there are some people who won't enjoy this screwball style of humor. Nevertheless, it has stood the test of time and it's still highly quotable ("Put the candle back!"). Plus, every time I watch this movie, I am impressed by how well they were able to capture the look and feel of the old Universal horror films. It's easy to see that Gene Wilder, Peter Boyle, Teri Garr, Cloris Leachman, Marty Feldman, and Madeline Kahn had a good time while making this parody.

Perhaps some of the references to the original might be lost on people who, like me, haven't seen the original 1931 film (it's certainly not required and basic knowledge of the premise should be enough but, from what I've looked up, it helps for the sake of maximum investment) but Young Frankenstein is still a really funny spoof film with a great performance from Gene Wilder, an obvious affection for the Universal Monsters movies (right down to using actual sets and props from the original film retooled for this new, more comedic context), memorable sequences, a great one-scene wonder in the form of Gene Hackman's blind hermit and good-looking B&W cinematography. Wish they kept that deleted scenes focusing on the recently deceased descendant of our main character, it was hilarious. A perfect spoof film for Halloween if you're seeking something more sophisticated than the raunchy, gross-out humour of Scary Movie (though I do still like that movie). Blazing Saddles is still the better film, though. That one qualifies as Mel Brooks' magnum opus in my eyes. It helps that it doesn't parody any specific Western. But they're both comedy classics either way :)

I am fond of Mel Brooks' films, and for me Young Frankenstein is my favourite of his and also one of my absolute favourites of the genre. It is wonderfully loopy and an ingenious send-up of universal horror clichés. Young Frankenstein is wonderfully shot in a sumptuous black and white, while the costumes, sets and make-up are wonderfully kooky. The story is fun too, while the script is hilariously quotable and Mel Brooks' direction is great. What gives Young Frankenstein real staying power is the marvellously done Puttin' on the Ritz musical number, the brain depository(outrageous to the point of being hilarious), the scene with Igor behind the book-shelves when they were looking the skulls(the facial expression and the breaking into song kills me every time), the old dad speech(then he just starts eating again), the hermit setting the monster's thumb on fire and the performances, with Gene Wilder giving one of his best performances as the infamous baron's grandson, and Peter Boyle almost stealing the show as the monster. The supporting performances are also a delight, Madeline Kahn's bride, Gene Hackman's blind hermit and Marty Feldman's hunchbacked Igor are very memorable. Overall, hysterically funny and kooky. 10/10 Bethany Cox

I just watched Young Frankenstein for the first time last week. And it is now competing for my favorite Mel Brooks movie. Spaceballs still holds a high position in my movie watching life, so it will be tough to ever top that. This film has the same vibe however. I really enjoyed it from the beginning. I’ve never been too crazy about monsters like Dracula, Werewolves, or Frankenstein. But when done well like anything else I appreciate it. As I was watching this movie it was clear that Mel was completely comfortable and in control of his direction and style that he wanted to do. The mix of spoof humor with spookiness is very well done and melded together. Gene Wilder is just a treasure as soon as his character, Dr Frederick Frankenstein, appears. The different take on this story is clever and just cheesy enough to not be annoying, but put a smile on my face! There was some crazy, zainy characters that could have been too much, but worked well with the tone the movie set from the beginning. I really felt Brooks had a pulse on what he wanted this movie to be. As I’ve said with other directors, Mel Brooks style will not be for everybody, but he has a clear plan for what he is setting out to do every time he makes a movie including here. There’s even a few small, clever, humorous twists that happen that are done well. I would recommend this movie to anybody that is a movie fan. Especially if you are a slap stick physical comedy fan. This is Gene Wilder at peak comedic performance. It was also nice to see Peter Boyle as the monster. And to see legendary actors Cloris Leachman and Gene Hackman was nice. I would see this movie if you haven’t yet, as I can tell how this movie is declared a classic by many!

Fans of Mel Brooks' movies will love Young Frankenstein, arguably his best film.  Those who fail to appreciate his humor will be left puzzled by the shenanigans, and that's perfectly understandable.  The movie is filled with slapstick, cringe-worthy puns, and silly ‘dad' jokes, but it is done with great style.  Part parody and part homage to James Whale's Frankenstein and Bride of Frankenstein, the film follows Dr Frederick Frankenstein (Gene Wilder) as he follows in his grandfather's footsteps in bringing life to the dead.  Featuring great sets, atmospheric lighting, beautiful black and white cinematography, and a fantastic cast that seems to be having a ball, it's a lot of fun to watch, despite the fact that a lot of the jokes miss the mark, especially if you're not a fan of Brooks' often juvenile humor.

I am fond of Mel Brooks' films, and for me Young Frankenstein is my favourite of his and also one of my absolute favourites of the genre. It is wonderfully loopy and an ingenious send-up of universal horror clichés. Young Frankenstein is wonderfully shot in a sumptuous black and white, while the costumes, sets and make-up are wonderfully kooky. The story is fun too, while the script is hilariously quotable and Mel Brooks' direction is great. What gives Young Frankenstein real staying power is the marvellously done Puttin' on the Ritz musical number, the brain depository(outrageous to the point of being hilarious), the scene with Igor behind the book-shelves when they were looking the skulls(the facial expression and the breaking into song kills me every time), the old dad speech(then he just starts eating again), the hermit setting the monster's thumb on fire and the performances, with Gene Wilder giving one of his best performances as the infamous baron's grandson, and Peter Boyle almost stealing the show as the monster. The supporting performances are also a delight, Madeline Kahn's bride, Gene Hackman's blind hermit and Marty Feldman's hunchbacked Igor are very memorable. Overall, hysterically funny and kooky. 10/10 Bethany Cox
8/10 it has aged well, really funny
One of my favourite films and the best Mel Brooks film by a mile.
We laugh every time we watch it. Hilarious!

The gags may be lame, and the script is almost infantile, but if you thought this film was funny in 1974, you'll likely get a kick out of it today.  There's an unembarrassed corniness about Young Frankenstein that generates plenty of belly laughs.  The monster's, "Puttin on the Ritz" number will even squeeze smiles out of those not inclined towards Brooks' brand of humor.

The vaguely smutty jokes and sight gags will go over well with teens, but the comic talents at work here will appeal to all.  Marty Feldman, Teri Garr, Madeline Kahn, Cloris Leachman, and Gene Hackman comprise a comedy's dream cast.  Peter Boyle brings a touch of dignity to the monster, and Gene Wilder is as charming and manic as he was in Willy Wonka.

Forget "Scream", forget "Scary Movie", and forget all the so-called horror comedies. This is the ultimate classic, full of off-the-wall moments. Some parody the classic 1931 film, while others are brand new. Probably Brooks' masterpiece.
Mel Brooks is at his absolute peak in comedic form.
Simply one of the best comedies ever put on celluloid.
One of my favorite go to comedies. Has some of the best one liners!
This movie and series Hunderby are the two funniest, wittiest and cleverest films ever created - IMHO.
Mel Brooks puts out some great movies. So many lol moments and homages to the original flick.
Incredibly funny with a great cast and beautiful music, it's a wonderful spoof of a great story that is thoroughly entertaining!
Classic comedy that everyone needs to see at least once
A very funny Mel Brooks film! Hilarious is the scene in which the little girl asks, 'What can we throw into the well next?', and the Monster comically rolls his eyes!
A lovingly made Classic!
Brook's best. Blobbo love.

It starts out decently, and gets progressively funny despite the long gaps between the jokes, but by the last third it just completely forgets to be a real comedy for some reason (aside from some disturbing sex jokes). It's much better than Robin Hood: Men In Tights but you can still do better.
The greatest scene is when Gene Wilder is kissing his co-star after they get married!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This, to me, is Mel Brooks’ best film. Not only does it function as a comedic take on the Frankenstein story, but it’s a really well made film: the sets, the cinematography, the earnestness of Gene Wilder. There’s not a single bad scene. That’s really all I can say about it. Otherwise, I would just repeat myself all day, and no one has time for that.
Even for the 70s, the effects are sub-par. I don't think it holds up well today. It was only mildly amusing.

Young Frankenstein is a very enjoyable spoof of the classic Universal Monster movies, as it pokes fun of them while also showing its appreciation for their craft. With writer/director Mel Brooks and main actor Gene Wilder adding a unique sense of charm and hilarity, this film ends up as one of the funniest parody films of all time.

I had really high hopes for this movie and it did not disappoint. Its humor is offbeat and reminiscent of Monty Python with Gene Wilder's over-the-top performance absolutely stealing the show. Of course Marty Feldman deserves a mention as the hilarious fourth-wall-breaking sidekick Igor. Despite a 1974 release, Young Frankenstein looks authentically vintage with its grainy, black and white imagery and less-than-stellar practical effects. All of these combine to make a wonderfully funny satire film.

Young Frankenstein is, to me, Mel Brooks' masterpiece. He was always at his best working with Gene Wilder and the two comic geniuses really shone in this film. The cast was perfect: Gene Wilder, Peter Boyle, Marty Feldman, Teri Garr, Madelyn Kahn, Cloris Leachman, and of course, Gene Hackman as the blind monk. Other supporting players were equally unforgettable: Kenneth Mars as Inspector Kemp, Richard Haydn as Heir Falkstein, and Liam Dunn as Mr. Hilltop (poor, poor Mr. Hilltop). It is a movie that goes from comedic scene to comedic scene in rapid succession, allowing just enough time to catch your breath before the next laugh.
Just can't beat this classic a must see A+++++++++++++
Absolute Classic.  Gene Wilder was the best.

A brilliant homage to the original. Overacted but perfectly so. Wilder is completely convincing even though he is constantly bumbling and delivering comedy. Teri Garr is accidentally sexy and plays her character with aplomb, terrible accent and all. The star studded cast delivers a witty and fun performance. Excellently quotable and always fresh.
Dumb Halloween movie. How is this movie considered a classic. This movie sucks.

Mostly not funny, unfortunately. Blind man and little girl scenes were.
Good acting.
I never get tired of watching this movie. Young Frankenstein is hilarious.
Mildly amusing but not as good as it's reputation.
A film that's so amazing and fine, no one can match to wilders performance. A movie that so great not even a review can do it justice
This could be the best comedy ever made and that is all you really need to know. Its brilliant, go watch it.

One of the greatest comedies of all time. Mel Brooks was a filmmaker who had delivered three critically successful films back to back with Young Frankenstein, Blazing Saddles and The Producers. Young Frankenstein doesn't attempt too much and it rests on the performances rather the set pieces. Gene Hackman's blind man scene is very funny and it's his performance that assists the comedy. Mel Brooks would continue making notable films but they would lose critical appeal with each new outing. Young Frankenstein was at the height of his filmmaking career at this landed with a loud impact at the box office. Very funny and quotable. 03/05/2020
This is a classic comedy, an absolute joy to watch. Gene wilder is incredible as well as the rest of the cast.

Young Frankenstein is beautifully creative, with set pieces being used from the original Frankenstein. It does get pretty funny at times but the comedy just goes up and down and I wanted to see more effective comedy. Gene Wilder's performance is perfect however and it's still quite a well done film.
Quite simply the greatest comedic film of the last 50 years

This - is my favorite comedy! A clever slapstick parody that's as much a love-letter (they use the original lab set) to the original 1931 film, as it is a commentary on the filmmaking and cultural differences forty-three years later. The jokes continue to crack and all of the leads kill it, with Madeline Kahn stealing her scenes in an incredibly talented cast. Clever scene wipes, mixed with more modern film making brings forth Brook's strengths as a director. Plus, you get to see the creation tap dance! The violin piece is particularly haunting the movie has heart that's not often present in these type of films. An essential movie in my opinion.
Brooks at his best I think. Top 10 all time comedy

Outstanding movie with amazing performances by a stellar cast. The height of Mel Brooks career. My only question to Rotten Tomatoes is why is this movie on a list of top 100 Horror movies and not on the list of top 100 comedies?

A hilarious classic. It may not quite be as good as Mel Brooks' masterpiece, Blazing Saddles, but it is in the same room. Tons of humor that isn't just related to sex. If you can get through this film without laughing, then you're like Squidward, a poor squid with a broken laugh box. The cinematography and scenes captured in black and white were, as said by another viewer, "awe inspiring". This movie can and will stand the test of time and be a prime example of what a comedy can and should be.
Mels best film. Epic.

A fearsome neo-noir comedy!

Mel Brooks' horror spoof Young Frankenstein (1974) is a flurry of fog lit paths, dark nights, candle lit rooms, and hilarious jokes! Brooks aimed to parody gothic literature's Mary Shelley's novel Frankenstein, which he accomplishes as he created one of the best adaptations of the book. Young Frankenstein is a dark and moody comedy taking on noir aesthetics with a light-hearted tone. All the jokes are good natured and silly enough for anyone to laugh along with because Mel Brooks and Gene Wilder write insanely creative punchlines. Young Frankenstein gives you euphemisms, metaphors, monologues, speeches, puns, dance numbers, and electric reanimation!

Brooks proves he is an all time great director with Young Frankenstein. Brooks finds morbid humor in the autopsy classroom, grave-robbing at night, reanimating the dead, and sleeping with a corpse. You witness beautiful cinematography at Wilder arrives in Transylvania's train station. The fog surrounds him, shrouding Wilder in mystery, the black background is eerie. All this in a comedy! I also love the grave-robbing sequence as it's creepy, then hilarious as the rain falls. The hypnotic violin melody is a legitimately beautiful theme for Young Frankenstein despite this film being a comedy. Mel Brooks is simply a comedic genius!

Gene Wilder is erratic as the mad scientist Dr. Frederick Frankenstein. His wide eyes and wild hair enthrall you the entire time you're watching Young Frankenstein. He gives a great melodramatic performance of madness as he screams, "Life!" Wilder pulls off endless medical dialogue and nonsense about bringing the dead back to life with total conviction. He sells the serious aspects of Young Frankenstein.

Teri Garr is gorgeous as Wilder's voluptuous assistant Inga. She is one of my favorite parts of Young Frankenstein because she is so free and fun loving. She's clearly having a wonderful time goofing around with Gene Wilder and completely sells her jokes with her easy going nature. She's adorable in Young Frankenstein! Garr plays up being scared, frustrated, and infatuated so well that you forget about the plot when she is on screen. I especially adore her perky German accent or whatever Garr was going for in Young Frankenstein.

Marty Feldman was born to play Igor in Young Frankenstein. His steady crouched walk, hunchback jokes, cross-eyed bits, and sarcastic commentary livens up the dreary style and serious performances. Feldman chews up the scenery and establishes himself as a comedic great.

Peter Boyle makes you feel genuine empathy for his version of Frankenstein's monster. He plays so many slapstick moments and verbal jokes with the perfect amount of groaning and fear. Boyle is The Monster and a massive presence in Young Frankenstein.

Madeline Kahn is just insanely funny as Elizabeth. Her fancy dressing and penchant for singing keeps you laughing whenever she is on screen. I love her little girl voice that she goes into for many of her jokes. It's so silly and fun that Kahn just steals scene after scene.

On the other hand, Cloris Leachman gives a fantastic turn as the movie's sort of villain Frau Blucher. Her expressive face and eyes give her a captivating gravitas for Young Frankenstein. I like the silly performance of heavy accent, to the point of being unintelligible, from Kenneth Mars as Inspector Hans Wilhelm Friedrich Kemp. His bit of moving his wooden hand or replacing his monocle over his eye patch is just too funny. I appreciate his overly heavy accent more each time I watch Young Frankenstein.

I have to mention the fact that Mel Brooks got Gene Hackman to cameo as the friendly blindman. His lonesome priest desiring a friend is funny as he delivers some of the funniest slapstick moments within Young Frankenstein with his soup and wine spilling gag. I particularly find Hackman endearing here as he realizes The Monster is mute.

Overall, Young Frankenstein is a timeless comedy of clever parody and peerless direction. Mel Brooks should be proud of this one forever. It's arguably his greatest film by all virtues of phenomenal filmmaking and outstanding acting.
Gene wilder and Gene Wilder never fail to put together a great film. Comedy and Si-Fi don't always work together but this one does.
One of my favorite movies from my childhood.
one of the funniest movies I've ever seen, I have nothing more to add

A fun and silly horror comedy with over the top characters, mild innuendos and a smattering of hit and miss jokes.  Good acting, story and setting, but it does drag on a bit in the second half and it also looks a bit cheap in parts, although this does add to the spoof style and charm.

The pitch-perfect way to make a satire, filmed with admiration to the source material, and poking fun at it at the same time. Young Frankenstein is a movie I watch on Halloween when instead of being frightened I'm ready to laugh.
Definitely on my top 10 list of comedy movies of all time. Perfectly cast impeccably directed by Mel Brooks

Young Frankenstein is a must-see Halloween classic. It's got all the elements to a perfect horror movie, but all the comedy to keep you laughing literally throughout all 105 minutes of it. Wildly enough, it's got all the necessary plot elements as the original, but tossed in with 200% more jokes, 200% more musical acts, and that much more love and affection towards its source material. And I hope to God they never remake this movie.

Read full review: jane-han.com/filmblog/2018/10/30/film-review-young-frankenstein-1974
Classic. Funny. A must see. Loved it since I was a kid.
Hysterical.  I watch this movie several times during the year. I love the Mel Brooks humor.  lol ??
I didnt think it was very funny or interesting folks! although i liked seeing Willy Wonka again. A much better and funnier Frankenstein was Andy Worhol's Flesh for Frankenstein
Now this was Mel Brooks at his best! The homage to older films, the jokes, and the performances were spot-on!

It's not only a spoof of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein, but it's a spoof of all Gothic Novels and the movies that have been inspired by them. Also it's a slap-stick comedy, and it works on all these levels! 

It pokes fun at every ridiculous Gothic cliché with a very inventive and various ways that still hold up to date. But it's the editing that stands out above the rest ways. Yes the editing! I can't remember if I've seen before a film editing that works this effectively in the comedy genre. It's so subtle and creative. 

Gene Wilder did it again with his charismatic and charming performance that must play a vital role in making the audience riveted whatever the movie he is in.

Unfortunately, there are some jokes that didn't land. Mostly because they were repetitive. Although they worked at the first time, they lost their sharpness and effectiveness very quickly, maybe even at the second time they were repeated. The rest of the jokes that didn't hit the mark, which is quite few, were just because I didn't find them funny.

I think Young Frankenstein is a very funny and unique comedy, and if I may choose between the two Mel Brooks films that have been released that year, Young Frankenstein and Blazing Saddles, I would choose Young Frankenstein.

(8/10)
Fantastic movie, my favorite Mel Brooks one.

Young Frankenstein has long been one of my favorite moves, and I think it is unappreciated as a comedy classic.  Since starting through the film in the movies by minute format on The Wilder Ride Podcast (www.thewilderride.com) I have come to appreciate the move and the cast even more.  Wilder and Mel Brooks have given us a labor of love in the Frankenstein cannon, and it is a crazy ride mixed with humor, jump scares, and a look into the mania that is Dr Frankenstein, and the human condition.

I know this is a classic, but it really hasn't aged well.  A lot of this genre doesn't appeal to me personally anyway, but it's hard to imagine that anyone who isn't already a Mel Brooks fan would enjoy this on first viewing in the 21st century...
It's hilarious, with timeless gags and and an insanely funny performance by Gene Wilder, but it's also a loving tribute to the golden age of horror.
Easily one of my favorite movies. Most people notice more gags after watching it several times I have found. Truly hilarious and dry humour that works very well.

I'm going to be a heretic here. After a few attempts I finally made it all the way through Young Frankenstein...and it just isn't funny, at all. The jokes are so lame, there's no wit, style or sophistication. Even the worst thing Woody Allen has ever done is like Shakespeare compared with this desperately unfunny offering. A comedy film for those without a sense of humour, perhaps? Notwithstanding the lack of any laughs, the film is beautifully shot and is a loving tribute to the Universal Frankenstein movies.

Mel Brooks directs this hilarious spoof of Mary Shelley's original source material with witty dialogue and brilliant performances by Gene Wilder and Peter Boyle as well as paying homage to horror films of the alike.
its a great family movie, funny jokes. i give it a 4 and a half because there are a couple curse words. i recommend it for nine and up maybe ten and up.
Loved this again Mel brooks zany comedy. Gene wilder is brilliant
A spoof in the guise of a spin-off/sequel, this Brooks film is funny, occasionally irreverent, and in any case, probably a worthy addition to the classic monster's legacy.
Some funny moments but nothing good really
I consider it a classic in its own right, as a comedy. While parts are over the top silly, other parts are slightly more serious, and seem a throwback to the original.

I feel like there's something I'm just not getting with this movie, everyone else seems to like it but all I see is a movie where some jokes land and I found myself laughing but most of the jokes have something to do with sex and aren't really funny and then there are the jokes that just don't make any sense but the movies acts as though they are knee-slappers

I have a hard time believing anyone would give this film a poor rating.  I don't contend that it's the greatest film of all time.  But I don't know of a comedy that is definitively better.  It's classic humor modernized(at its time) and excellently executed by an ensemble cast that delivers flawless performances.  Perfectly paced and presented with self-awareness and wonderfully crafted homages to vintage horror hallmarks while adding smart originality of a comedic bent. Feldman, Wilder, Kahn, Leachman and Brooks at their finest and funniest.
Werewolf to Therewolf to Therehorse to Therecastle is one of the best jokes ever.
My favorite Mel Brooks/Gene Wilder collaboration it , in my opinion, ranks among the funniest movies of all time. An excellent cast who all work to create a classic movie.
Subtle humor done right. Absolutely perfect.
A great and hilarious movie!
This is a good movie, but isn't really as hilarious as everyone says it is. "Young Frankenstein" has its moments, and is mostly pretty enjoyable.
A movie well ahead of its time, 'Young Frankenstein' isn't as funny as some of Mel Brooks' other films, but it's the best. Final Score: 8.9/10
I would give this film a 95% overall rating.

10 out of 10:

Young Frankenstein manages to stay accurate to its source material with funny moments, memorable dialogue, and an insane performance from Gene Wilder.
Perfect way to wash out the terrible feeling of "Wonder" I was supposed to feel this weekend!
The greatest movie of all time!
One of the best Gene Wilder performances of his career. So sad he died in August of 2016. Overall, a HILARIOUS movie!

I love seeing that girl who was in Paper Moon and Whats Up Doc? She's always a good laugh. That blonde is beyond cute and sexy. I remember seeing her in Close Encounters of the Third Kind and thinking the same thing. She's really something. Igor is hilarious, played by Marty. 

Great transition with the hanging. When the girl starts singing while having sex, hahaha.

This was a really funny movie that respects the original by staying true to some of the story. Marty Feldman was hilarious along with Madeline Kahn.

This is by far the best movie made by Mel Brooks.  Gene Wilder is excellent in the role of the descendant of Dr Frankenstein. And the fact that it was made in Back & White just helps create the ultimate finish to a horror spoof.
Feldman steals the show, and a funny show it is, too.
While I don't like it as much as most, I will not deny that this is FUNNY. Other crappy spoof movies need to take notes from this and Mel Brooks' other classic spoofs.
Only Igor kinda funny. Liked the atmosphere

Many years ago I saw Young Frankenstein and I remember enjoying it just like I do with almost all Mel Brooks movies. It wasn't until this rewatch that I realized...it might be his best movie. The effort they put into making it look like a classic black-and-white monster movie is totally worth it. It feels like the perfect spoof of a classic.

Gene Wilder is hilarious. He plays anger for comedy better than anyone I know. The opening scene where he starts ranting at a student in his class was great! One of my favorite aspects was how Wilder and Marty Feldman played off each other. That kind of silly banter is totally my kind of comedy. "There wolf" is such a stupid joke but I was laughing so hard. 

There's lots of other great performances by amazing actors in this movie. Peter Boyle, Madeline Kahn, Teri Garr, etc. and all of them are at the top of their game. There's even a cameo by an unrecognizable Gene Hackman that was great. I suppose what I'm trying to say is that Young Frankenstein really worked for me. It's a superb comedy, and it reminds me how great spoof movies used to be.

Yes this is my first time seeing this highly regarded film and I wish I had seen it sooner. With solid performances, great production, a huge amount of gags throughout, a good score and an iconic dance number to boot this is a spoof that might not be high brow but is funny nonetheless.

Young Frankenstein is very well made technically and so well acted with Gene Wilder being excellent in his iconic role and the film is quite funny at times with a couple of terrific scenes, but it is overall pretty uneven with some jokes being great, but with others being not so great. It doesn't quite succeeds as a parody film as it only manages to utilize its premise in approximately half of the movie with the other half being dull, unfunny and forgettable. It is a solid, but very disappointing film.

There is no way I can classify this as a horror movie. But this is one of the greatest comedy movies of all time no questions asked. With an all star cast of Gene Wilder, Peter Boyle, Madeline Kahn, cloris Leachman, and marty feildman you cant go wrong. Especially when you have the legendary Mel Brooks. In Robin hood : men in tights Mel says a joke : " Loxley and bagel, can't miss" I feel the same with Brooks and wilder. 

If you have not seen this movie I am seriously wondering why you havent
truely amazing movie.
A hilarious film with some truly excellent performances.
One of the best comedies of all time. A classic.

My personal favorite Mel Brooks movie, and I would argue the best parody film ever made. Modern spoof movies, please take note. What Brooks has done here is painstakingly recreate the atmosphere and design of the original Universal horror classic. He has set this up to be what looks like a legitimate film from that genre and era but then he completely turns it on his head. He's not just tossing in random references to past movies or trends. There's a set up for a joke that uses a reference to deliver the punchline. There's honest to God affection for these older horror films on display here.

As always, the casting is perfect. Gene Wilder, Peter Boyle, Marty Feldman, Terri Garr, Madeline Kahn, and Kenneth Mars (my favorite actor in this movie) all do an excellent job playing the material straight while still winking at the camera. It's the right balance.

Young Frankenstein is a perfect comedy with a heart.

This is my favourite Mel Brooks film. Parody at its finest! The use of original Frankenstein movie set pieces / instruments is great addition and references to several characters and incidents from several other Frankenstein films/books adds many inside jokes. I literally love the cast, too. Perfect. Rating: 9 / 10
Fun, funny, and entertaining!  A great cast!

Young Frankenstein is directed and co-written by Mel Brooks, and it stars Gene Wilder, Peter Boyle, Marty Feldman, Cloris Leachman, and Teri Garr in a parody film of Frankenstein about a grandson of Dr. Victor Frankenstein that doesn't want any involvement with his grandfather's work, that is until he goes to his grandpa's place to see what he has done. When I saw Gene Wilder's passing, I felt like watching one of his well known films which is this, which when I first saw this movie, I thought it was boring and but only have some chuckle moments, but I was at my teen years at the time, so I wasn't quite getting a grasp of Mel Brooks films. So at second viewing, this is a lot better than I first saw of it. Gene Wilder is great for being the straight man, but when he goes insane, it's a lot of fun to watch. It has a cameo by Gene Hackman who is known for his serious and villainous roles, and he's probably one of the funniest parts of the film. I was relived to see that I didn't need to watch the original film in order to understand the jokes in this as I'm assuming that the serious parts that were in the original film were played in a comedic way that doesn't make fun of the film that was making a parody of. The jokes really work in a very silly way, and the characters are very memorable in a way that they are very funny. It does show that they are making this as a bit of a tribute to the original film as they care very much about it, and probably wanted to be similar to the movie. Young Frankenstein is a classic comedy that is one of Mel Brooks's best.
One of my all time favorites!
Gene Wilder and Marty Feldman do a great job of acting in this hilarious movie.
Absolutley hilarious!
A masterpiece that must be seen by directors & producers to comprehend and save spoof film genre from the current state of doom.

One of my favourite comedies, it makes me laugh every time, Marty Feldman and Gene Wilder made a hilarious comedic duo!  And i love how they rendered the atmosphere (music and blurred image too) of old horror movies!

Mel Brooks' spoof of classic Universal horror films, Young Frankenstein is neither an amazing comedy nor a completely lame one, and it managed to conjure up a few decent belly laughs from me; though I wished there were more. Gene Wilder brilliantly stars as Dr. Frederick Frankenstein (pronounced "Fronkensteen" so as not to be confused with his ancestor) who wants to steer as far away from his family's legacy as possible, but soon finds himself consumed by the science of re-animation and it's a riot watching him perform. The other stand-out from the cast is Marty Feldman as Igor (pronounced eye-gor) who is essentially the embodiment of an internet troll, constantly challenging Frankenstein's methods and breaking the fourth wall repeatedly. It's a gag-filled film throughout and I feel it hits more than misses, especially during a random encounter between the Monster and a blind, old man played surprisingly by Gene Hackman that used physical comedy flawlessly! It's exactly what you'd expect from a Mel Brooks film, it's witty, silly, has a random dance number for no reason at all, and overall it's a solid comedy that produces laughs and spoofs the classic, Frankenstein story to a T.

For a needlessly precise numerical rating: 86/100, or A-
A gobsmackingly hilarious parody/conflation/sequel of the first two Frankenstein films. It helps that Bride of Frankenstein is essentially a camp take on the first film, so the film only has to faithfully replicate the visual style and tone of the films and then nudge them just a bit more into the direction of comedy- a little police captain with an immovable fake arm here, a little Doctor and Monster "Putting on the Ritz" there.

One of my personal favorites of Brooks. Wilder is perfect is Frederick Frankenstein (it's pronounced Frankunsteen), and his craziness is perfectly believable. The brightest spot in this film, for me, is Marty Feldman is Igor (prounced Eyegor). He is the funny guy, the one that throws the curveballs and doesn't appear to take anything seriously. If you have not seen this film, stop reading these reviews and go watch it.
One of the best comedies period. From the scene where he abuses the old man and says to give him an extra dollar to the singing near the end, it's full of laughs... What hump?
Gene wilder and Mel brooks create for us a perfect comedy, with great timing and hilarious writing, this sets the bar for spoofs and comedies, and will most probably never be surpassed.
Never have I laughed so hard at the ending of a comedy. Wonderful stuff.
One of the greatest comedies of all time. Gene Wilder, and Marty Feldman's chemistry elevate the comedy past the script alone.

Young "Fronkensteen" is fun for the family. It's Mel Brooks' finest piece of film that made parodist fans begging for more from him. Mel brought along Blazing Saddles, Spaceballs, The Producers, and even Robin Hood: Men in Tights after the massive success of this film. Also, I must say. Gene Wilder is phenomenal in this movie. He's hilarious. It's fun for the family. Despite there being inappropriate moments, like the "roll in ze hay", it's a movie you shouldn't miss.
A fine retelling of the classic Frankenstein story, with a great comedic twist from Brooks.

This funny, well acted parody of Universals horror films of the 1930s is without a doubt Mel Brooks' best picture! And if you are thinking about seeing the new frankenstein movie don't! Watch this one instead :) You will thank me later!

One of Mel Brooks' more nuanced comedies, "Young Frankenstein" focuses less on the zany, multiple-jokes-per-minute comedic approach and more on the basic situational humor found within its surprisingly inspired narrative. This novel reimagining of the classic Mary Shelley tale contains no shortage of wit, sardonicism, or irony. And it's performed with expert comedic precision. Gene Wilder, Terri Garr, Cloris Leachman, and Peter Boyle are all on point, but the real show-stealer here is Mary Feldman, in his most well-known filmic role. Hard to imagine Brooks releasing this just a few months after the raucously madcap "Blazing Saddles." In comparison though, "Young Frankenstein" does seem like the more subdued, higher-browed testament to Mel Brooks' versatility in the comedic craft. Good stuff.
One of Mel Brook's best classics.

Gene Wilder's greatest achievement (along with Willy Wonka).  I suspect that he spent the rest of his career chasing this level of success.  The movie plot is executed flawlessly and has a steady flow of laughs from beginning to end.  However, it's Peter Boyle who steals the show here.  The film has several classic lines and gags.  This spoof on the original Frankenstein was the model for following films such as Airplane!, Scary Movie, etc.  Arguable Mel Brooks' finest works.

Mel Brooks delivers a loving homage to the classic Universal Monster Movies with the hilarious Young Frankenstein.  Mainly drawn from the first three Frankenstein films (especially Son of Frankenstein), the story follows Dr. Frankenstein's grandson Frederick, who inherits the family estate and discovers his grandfather's private journal which contains the secret to re-animating life.  Starring Gene Wilder, Peter Boyle, Teri Garr, and Madeline Kahn, the film has a strong cast; Wilder in particular is outstanding, really nailing the comedy.  And Brooks does a brilliant job at emulating the classic look and feel of old Hollywood films.  Yet the humor can be a little broad and overly slapsticky at times.  Still, Young Frankenstein is incredibly fun and delivers a lot of laughs.
Upon inheriting his grandfather's castle, a neurologist follows the family tradition in this hilarious Mel Brooks film.

A great cast in a Mel Brooks movie. And Mel Brooks movies are, well, Mel Brooks movies. Either you like him or you don't. Personally, I'm not much of a fan of lowbrow stuff like this, with silly sight gags and insider humor. But this one is watchable and fun, mainly because of Gene Wilder and Madeline Kahn. For me there weren't any belly laughs, just some fun amusement.

The art of the spoof has been lost in recent years, or at least a fundamental understanding of what makes the greatest spoofs work at the most basic level. What makes them great can be summed up in one word: Love. It's strange to think about, but the best film spoofs are a built on an inherent love and understanding of what's being skewered. So it's no surprise in some ways that Young Frankenstein is Mel Brooks' greatest film. The amount of referential material in this film goes far beyond the knowledge of even some seasoned film geeks (there is a Frankenstein film that features a police inspector that has a wooden arm, and yes, he plays darts with Dr. Frankenstein). Even the equipment in this film's lab is taken from the Boris Karloff classic. Combine this reverence with one of Gene Wilder's greatest performances, jokes that absolutely hit their mark, and gorgeous atmosphere from black and white cinematography, and you have a comedy classic. One of the greatest of all time and highly recommended.
This is a fun spoof movie with a great cast.

I'm not a fan of Mel Brooks but when I watch Young Frankenstein I can see what the fans see in his movies. His other movies I find are like SNL skits and I'm definitely not an SNL fan. Also I can't stand seeing Mel in his movies. He always plays the most obvious and annoying characters, and to make things worst he seems like a really nice guy so I feel bad not liking him. What Mel Brooks does was perfected in Young Frankenstein and it proves that his kind of humor can work when it's done right. It just seems like he put a lot of thought into this one, where his other movies it seems like the first joke to pop into his head is what he'd use no matter how unfunny it might be. I adored this on TV growing up in the 70's, even before I had seen any other Frankenstein film, but now, seeing it on blu, it was even more wonderful than I had remembered. Teri Garr and Peter Boyle were big surprises for me, along with the usual outstanding work by Gene Wilder and Madeline Kahn. Mel Brooks' set pieces and directorial style were outstanding and paid homage very lovingly, getting things from the original Shelley 1818 text that even earlier Frankenstein films hadn't. Boris Karloff's daughter, interviewed, said that she loved it, and that her famous father had a great sense of humour and would have loved it as well. The conclusion of an outstanding run of 3 masterpieces in 4 films for Brooks, unfortunately never to be equaled.

Young Frankenstein is a very different parody film you get compared to the modern crop of spoofs. Rather than throwing out joke after joke on a variety of horror subjects, Mel Brooks and Writer/Star Gene Wilder keeps it based on the story of Frankenstein. Young Frankenstein is essentially a version of that story. 
Gene Wilder is great as the shouting mad scientist and delivers the jokes with ease. Peter Boyle makes the most of what he can as the monster. Cloris Leachman is fun to watch but not in the film enough. However, she does have some of the best scenes. The highlight out of all the characters is Marty Feldman as Igor. He has the look for the character and the voice that you don't expect. He is given some of the best jokes, and the way he connects to the audience by talking to them works well. There is also a nice little cameo from Gene Hackman.
It also helps Brooks to be given equipment from the original Frankenstein film to use. Along with the well crafted sets, you are given a Frankenstein film that feels authentic. The use of filming it in black and white gives it that extra layer. 
Whilst the film contains some good jokes, a lot of them are based on the Universal horror film series. This means that some of the humour can be lost on the audience. You also have to be paying attention as some jokes could fly straight past you without realising. It wasn't until reading through the quotes after that I could appreciate some of the one liners I missed. Still, two of the best sequences (the charades and the performance) should be found funny to anyone who isn't familiar with the movies.
Whilst I personally didn't find it to be Mel Brook's best comedy, it is still a solid affair. Unfortunately, I find that the film would only gain a particular audience based on their past viewing history.
A film I once loved has been reduced to a fond memory over time!
The best spoof movie ever. Hilarious and perfectly cast, Young Frankenstein is a masterpiece.

Relentlessly silly, as Mel Brooks movies tend to go. Gene Wilder's role in the screenwriting is apparent though, compared to Brooks' solo works. Wilder keeps the satire in sharp focus, allowing the silliest of jokes to remain in line with the  homage/parody of classic horror movies. The results hit far more often than miss, but there are so many great jokes that the misses may actually be weaker hits. Flawless recreation of 1930s cinematography / score / lighting, used for both jarringly funny jokes and plot development (ex. The mysterious violin we had assumed was just the score). Awesome use of editing to pack greater punches in the jokes. JOKE SPOILER: The best example of this is the sexual "tension" between Dr. Frunkunshteen (Gene Wilder) and his assistant Inga (Teri Garr). For most of the film, it seems entirely one-sided, Inga reading everything that the Doctor says in a sexual way. Near the end of the movie, Inga continues to flirt, only for the Doctor to have a seemingly non-sexual revelation. (Like, dude, how are you NOT seeing this?) Cut to next scene in an empty laboratory, when innocuous dialogue is traded while the camera slowly pans to the Doctor and Inga naked under the covers. So wonderful. Gosh, the acting, too. Gene Wilder may have the most screen time, but this feels much more like an ensemble work. Peter Boyle as the Monster, Marty Feldman as Igor, Madeline Kahn as Elizabeth the eventual Bride of the Monster, Cloris Leachman as Frau Blucher (NNNNEEEEIIIIGGHGHHBBRBRRB), even a cameo from Gene Hackman, pretty famous at the time for his starring role in The French Connection, as a Transylvanian blind man looking for a friend to share soup, cigars, and espresso with. It's easier to appreciate Young Frankenstein if you have seen films like, duh, Frankenstein, but the jokes in this parody are aplenty and so tangible that it well stands the test of time. Even the "Puttin' on the Ritz" routine, thanks to Peter Boyle's autistic enthusiasm for singing and dancing. You laugh with him, not at him -- Key to a fantastic parody.
1of the funniest movies of all time!!

Mel Brooks and Gene Wilder craft the film with an evident fondness for the original, and they still succeed in making it a hilariously goofy parody - one of Brooks' most buoyant and developed efforts.

Mel Brooks' spoof of the Universal Pictures Frankenstein series is actually a lovingly recreated homage in black and white that is played surprisingly straight despite the ridiculousness that is heaped on in generous portions. Gene Wilder (whose idea this apparently was) plays Frederick Fronkensteen, descendent of the original mad scientist who returns to his ancestral home in Transylvania (as in Son of Frankenstein, 1939). There he meets I-gor (played hysterically by googly-eyed Marty Feldman) and Inga his assistant (played by Teri Garr). Peter Boyle steals the show as the Monster he creates- who could forget his rendition of "Putting on the Ritz"? I don't laugh at most comedies but I laughed at this one (even having seen it many times before). No doubt it holds up because of its affection for the original.
very entertaining, a cult classic with extremely unique characters.
Although I didn't find this that funny, this movie is actually very good. Gene Wilder was awesome, and the numerous satirical references worked well.

Mel Brooks' greatest film.  This parody of the classic novel and movie "Frankenstein" is both silly, smart, clever, and inventive, making this an enjoyable experience for all audiences.  Mel Brooks and Gene Wilder's Oscar-nominated script gives moviegoers a great taste of infectious humor, and a bizarre, interesting story that mimics part of the original story, and works.  Gene Wilder gives an amazing performance of Dr. Frederick Frankenstein (Froonk-en-steen), which makes up most of the laughs, but also has perfect support from Peter Boyle as the Monster, Marty Feldman as Igor (I-gore), Madeline Kahn as Elizabeth, and Cloris Leachman as Frau BlÃ¼cher.  The film also has great makeup, perfect black-and-white background and cinematography that creates the look of the 1931 classic, perfect production design, and amazing set design that make the film look more like the original film without giving us loads of comedy.  It has some of the original's feel, but mainly has its own feel that's comedic and silly at times.  The film is incredibly funny, well directed, written, and acted, and the best Frankenstein parody ever made.  The film is worth watching for all Brooks and parody fans.

Satire doesn't have to be cynical (I'm looking at you, Farrelly and Zucker brothers of the world.) Mel Brooks' "Young Frankenstein" manages to at once act as over-the-top, immature spoof of Warner Bros horror movies and joyous homage to the notion of old Hollywood showmanship and what makes movies great. Even if not riotously funny, this is comedy with dog ears, stained pages in a schoolboy joke book that Brooks elevates not only to the big screen and brings to an audience, but like the best of his work it's a welcome cheer to the fact that THIS can be a profession, and that with a little risk, creativity and BALLS -- what knockers! -- pop culture is never really dead -- it's just always waiting to be brought back to life.
I miss u my Der Gene Wilder you made crazy thing inovation with Mel i supposed that everyone are insane! love from the distance my loyal handsome Wolfy!
Unlike most modern parodies you find in the cinemas, Brooks and Wilder's homage to classic horror is able to deliver consistent humor along with a coherent plot and likeable characters.

Directed by Mel Brooks and starring Gene Wilder with Marty Feldman and Teri Garr, this comedy films parodies old horror films like the original Frankenstein. However, it also functions as a drama in its own right much like the original Frankenstein films. Wilder is a professor and the grandson of Victor Frankenstein. The thing is, he wants nothing to do with his infamous relative, even going so far as pronouncing his name differently. However, when he inherits the family estate he must face his ancestry head on. There temptation takes over and he begins to build a creature of his very own, with horrifyingly funny results. This film has memorable moments including "Putting on the Ritz" and the Inspector's arm. I still cannot believe that Feldman's eyes get that big either! Wow.
The film was rather boring. Weird as well.
Not one of Mel Brooks' best, but still better than most comedies.
Possibly Mel Blanc's best film. No need to have actually seen the three original MGM Frankenstein films, but it would help a bit. The cast is great to the last credit!
I do love me some Mel Brooks, and I love this one best of all.  The performances are all stellar, and the loving detail in tribute to the great horror films is just terrific.
An absolute classic.

Hilarious film. Love the old frankenstein movies and think this is a great spoof. For any frankenstein lover!

The humor was pretty lame. But a great spoof. Gene Wilder is always great!
A great, laughable classic that still holds its charms and wits after four long decades. Mel Brooks and Gene Wilder successfully made a timeless spoof about Frankenstein.
